summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with Jeff McKenzie, a former SigNet employee, conducted on September 22, 2021. The interview focuses on McKenzie's role in responding to a video system failure at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019. Investigators question McKenzie about the timeline of the system failure, the attempts to repair it, and the potential impact of FBI seizure of the equipment on data recovery.

persons.name: Jeff McKenzie
persons.role: Former SigNet Senior Customer Support Representative
persons.context: Former SigNet employee interviewed by DOJ OIG about his involvement in the MCC video system repair request in August 2019, around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. He provided technical support and was on vacation during part of the incident.

persons.name: Dennis
persons.context: DOJ OIG Senior Special Agent conducting the interview with Jeff McKenzie. He asks clarifying questions about the timeline and technical details of the MCC video system failure.

persons.name: Justin Houston
persons.context: SigNet employee who was also assigned to the MCC service request and was on vacation during the incident. McKenzie believes initial contact from the MCC may have been to Houston.

persons.name: Jeff Cranor
persons.context: SigNet employee assigned to the MCC service request. He was a former Bureau of Prisons employee with knowledge of the Nice Vision video system.

persons.name: Derek Barr
persons.context: Senior Support Engineer for Qognify (the video software manufacturer) who provided technical instructions for rebuilding the RAID array in the MCC's video system.

persons.name: Steve Smith
persons.context: SigNet sales representative who worked with the Bureau of Prisons. McKenzie mentioned reaching out to him during the incident.

connections.description: Dennis, a DOJ OIG Senior Special Agent, is interviewing Jeff McKenzie as part of an investigation into Epstein's death and the MCC video system failure.
Both were SigNet employees assigned to the same service request for the MCC. McKenzie believes Houston may have been the initial point of contact.
Both were SigNet employees. Cranor may have had some interaction with the MCC staff on the case, especially if McKenzie and Houston were unavailable.
McKenzie reached out to Derek Barr at Qognify for technical support on how to rebuild the failed RAID array in the MCC's video system.

events.title: MCC Video System Failure Reported
events.description: A SigNet service request is created for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after a RAID array crash is reported. Jeff McKenzie receives or is assigned to the case.

events.title: Drive Replacement Attempt and FBI Seizure
events.description: MCC staff member gains access to the DVR room and attempts to replace failed hard drives. The FBI arrives on site and seizes the entire video recording system while drives are reportedly in the process of rebuilding.

events.title: Potential Initial Drive Failure
events.description: Investigators suggest the video system drives may have initially gone bad on this date, prior to the official service request on August 8th.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview of Jeff McKenzie
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary interview with former SigNet employee Jeff McKenzie regarding the MCC video system issues surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
Fairfax, Virginia (Location of Orion Systems Group)
keyFacts: The interview focuses on a video system (RAID array) failure at the MCC that occurred around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019.
Jeff McKenzie, the SigNet technician, indicates the FBI seized the video recording equipment from the MCC on Saturday, August 10, 2019, while drives were in the process of being rebuilt.

McKenzie's technical assessment suggests that removing drives during a rebuild or losing two drives in a RAID 5 array would corrupt the video database and wipe all data, complicating recovery of any footage.
The service request timeline shows MCC staff had difficulty accessing the DVR room and obtaining replacement drives, causing delays in the repair attempt.
The document is part of a DOJ OIG investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances, specifically the preservation of video evidence.
